awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:   Fire Influences on Forest Recovery and Associated Ecosystem Feedbacks in Arctic Larch Forests.

por.por_cntn:
This project used a combination of field measurements and satellite images to improve our understanding of wildfire dynamics in boreal forests of northeastern Siberia. Among the key outcomes is a new publicly available fire perimeter database that contains more detail than existing data sets. This database helped to quantify a dramatic increase in fires above the Arctic Circle during the extreme fire seasons of 2019 and 2020, and will be a valuable tool for other researchers studying wildfire in this region. Results from this project also show burning is quite patchy within the boundaries of individual fires. This is important for understanding how plants grow back after fire, and especially whether regrowth is dominated more by trees or shrubs. Additional project analyses showed that traditional techniques for measuring vegetation recovery with satellite data cannot easily distinguish between trees and shrubs, and that data from drones can help capture fine-scale patterns of plant regrowth, highlighting the importance of new data and tools. 

 

Fires alter how much sunlight is absorbed by the land surface, and this often leads to a climatic cooling effect in the decades after fire. Project research using the new fire database showed that as fires occur further north, the strength of this cooling effect is diminished. Additional analyses found that enhanced tree regrowth after fire can further reduce cooling, or even lead to a climatic warming effect. These results highlight the importance of post-fire vegetation growth for understanding how wildfires affect climate. This is especially important in northeastern Siberia because it is a large area that experiences as much or more burning than boreal forests in Alaska and Canada. 

 

The findings from this project help us understand how ongoing increases in fire activity in northeastern Siberia are likely to influence climate in the coming decades. In addition to the scientific outcomes, this project provided training opportunities for numerous undergraduate students and several postdoctoral scholars. These included involvement in field work and technical skill development, and involved a number of students from identity groups that are underrepresented in STEM fields. Project data and subject matter have been incorporated into a number of undergraduate courses as well. Despite complications related to the COVID-19 pandemic and the war in Ukraine, the project has also fostered international scientific collaboration.
